pyGMLMhelper¶

This submodule contains convenience wrappers for performing operations like maximum likelihood estimation.

class pyGMLM.pyGMLMhelper.GMLMHelper(gmlm: pyGMLM.pyGMLMcuda.kcGMLM)¶

Wrapper class for the kcGMLM object (built in pybind11). Helps access the C++ functions of that class for operations like optimization.

This is for the GMLM likelihood only: no hyperparameters are used or considered by the functions in this class.

property GMLM_structure: pyGMLM.pyGMLMcuda.ModelStructure¶

The GMLM structure.

__init__(gmlm: pyGMLM.pyGMLMcuda.kcGMLM)¶
Parameters

gmlm – The constructed built kcGMLM object.

_get_F(factor: int, factor_idxs: list[int], dim_F: int, params_group: pyGMLM.pyGMLMcuda.ParametersGroup) → numpy.ndarray¶

Computes the full coefficient for a factor using the Khatri-Rao product

Parameters

  • factor – whether or not to compute the derivatives too.

  • factor_idxs – the factor numbers of each mode

  • dim_F – the total size expected for this factor

  • params_group – the tensor group’s parameters object

Returns

The full factor coefficients.

compute_gradient_and_negative_log_likelihood_vectorized(param_vector: numpy.ndarray) → tuple[float, numpy.ndarray]¶

Computes the negative log likelihood and gradient for a set of vectorized parameters.

Parameters

param_vector – Flattened parameters in order: W, B, Group[0].V, Group[0].T[0], …, Group[0].T[S_0-1], Group[1].V, Group[1].T[0], …

Returns

A tuple (f,g)

f (float): Log likelihood.

g (np.ndarray): Flattened gradient in order: -dW, -dB, -Group[0].dV, -Group[0].dT[0], …, -Group[0].dT[S_0-1], -Group[1].dV, -Group[1].dT[0], …

Raises

RuntimeError – if the GMLM has not been sent to the GPU

compute_gradient_negative_log_likelihood_vectorized(param_vector: numpy.ndarray) → numpy.ndarray¶

Computes the gradient of the negative log likelihood for a set of vectorized parameters.

Parameters

param_vector – Flattened parameters in order: W, B, Group[0].V, Group[0].T[0], …, Group[0].T[S_0-1], Group[1].V, Group[1].T[0], …

Returns

-dW, -dB, -Group[0].dV, -Group[0].dT[0], …, -Group[0].dT[S_0-1], -Group[1].dV, -Group[1].dT[0], …

Return type

Flattened gradient in order

Raises

RuntimeError – if the GMLM has not been sent to the GPU

randomize_parameters(std: float = 1.0)¶

Sets all the parameters to be i.i.d. normal with mean 0 and the given standard deviation.

Parameters

std (float) – the standard deviation (defaults to 1 for standard normal).

Builds a vectorized form of the gradient of the current results (of log likelihood, not negative log likelihood).

dW, dB, Group[0].dV, Group[0].dT[0], …, Group[0].dT[S_0-1], Group[1].dV, Group[1].dT[0], …

Return type

class pyGMLM.pyGMLMhelper.GMLMHelperCPU(gmlm: pyGMLM.pyGMLMcuda.kcGMLM)¶
__init__(gmlm: pyGMLM.pyGMLMcuda.kcGMLM)¶

Puts all the trials together into one compact structure for computing the log likelihood and derivative using numpy computations.

This still uses the GMLM data in the C++ objects. This choice I made is annoying, but it keeps all the trial checking & organizing code the same for both the CPU and GPU versions. Currently, I don’t plan to make a Python version of the class holding all the GMLM data, despite the fact that it’d be easier to work with. So for now, the C++ module must still be compiled even to run this numpy version (with cmake option ‘-DWITH_GPU=Off’ to not require the CUDA library if desired). Sorry for the inconvenience.

Parameters

GMLMHelper – The GMLM object

Raises

ValueError – if the trial setup doesn’t work

_get_DfDT(mode, mode_idxs, dim_F, params_group)¶

Helper function for building a structure for derivative computation.

compute_gradient_and_negative_log_likelihood_vectorized(param_vector: numpy.ndarray) → tuple[float, numpy.ndarray]¶

Computes the negative log likelihood and gradient for a set of vectorized parameters. Computations done on CPU;

Parameters

param_vector – Flattened parameters in order: W, B, Group[0].V, Group[0].T[0], …, Group[0].T[S_0-1], Group[1].V, Group[1].T[0], …

Returns

A tuple (f,g)

f (float): Log likelihood.

g (np.ndarray): Flattened gradient in order: -dW, -dB, -Group[0].dV, -Group[0].dT[0], …, -Group[0].dT[S_0-1], -Group[1].dV, -Group[1].dT[0], …

compute_negative_log_likelihood_vectorized(param_vector: numpy.ndarray) → float¶

Computes the negative log likelihood for a set of vectorized parameters. Computations done on CPU;

derivative_log_like_function(log_rate: numpy.ndarray, Y: numpy.ndarray) → tuple[numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray]¶

Computes the log likelihood and derivative for each bin given the linear term and observed spike counts.

Parameters

  • log_rate – linear term in each bin. For Poisson with exponential nonlinearity, this is the log spike rate.

  • Y – spike count in each bin. Should be the same size as log_rate

Returns

(log likelihood of each bin. Same size as log_rate and Y, derivative of the log likelihood of each bin. Same size as log_rate and Y)

log_like_function(log_rate: numpy.ndarray, Y: numpy.ndarray) → numpy.ndarray¶

Computes the log likelihood for each bin given the linear term and observed spike counts.

Parameters

  • log_rate – linear term in each bin. For Poisson with exponential nonlinearity, this is the log spike rate.

  • Y – spike count in each bin. Should be the same size as log_rate

Returns

Log likelihood of each bin. Same size as log_rate and Y

toGPU() → None¶

Overwrites the toGPU function for the helper to raise an error - this type of object will not send to GPU.
